awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling and simulation of out-of-equilibrium processes in Epitaxy
awd_abstract_narration:
Ratsch/Margetis/Gibou
1412392/1412769/1412695

     Epitaxial growth is a process in which one material is deposited on top of another.  It is of fundamental technological importance, as many modern opto-electronic devices are fabricated by this process.  Important examples include transistors in microelectronics, quantum dots for photonic crystal lasers, quantum dot-based product enhancements in the energy sector, and nonvolatile storage media, which are sought to replace hard drives, flash memories, and RAM memories.  Other applications include, for example, catalysts (speeding up chemical reactions), which often rely on metal epitaxy.  Catalysis is used in the energy sector, in food processing, in environmental science, and elsewhere; a well-known example is the catalytic converter for vehicle emissions control.  The investigators of this collaborative project develop models that lead to a better and more fundamental understanding of epitaxial growth.  Results of the work are of interest not only to mathematicians but also to physicists, material scientists and engineers, and medical scientists to whose problems the mathematical results apply.  Three graduate students are included in this interdisciplinary project. 

     The goal of the project is to develop analytical and computational tools to seamlessly and efficiently connect several length and time scales in epitaxy.  These tools encompass asymptotic methods for linking atomistic models to mesoscale phenomena as well as efficient numerical methods on adaptive quadtree/octree grids in a parallel computing environment to enable the simulation of large material systems.  The investigators design and implement a hierarchy of growth models that combine atomistic master equations in the context of kinetic solid-on-solid models, density-functional theory (DFT), a partial differential equation-based island dynamics growth model, and an efficient scheme to solve the elastic equations to include elastic strain.  This collaborative effort provides the means to address a long-standing controversy about the role played by kinetic and thermodynamics effects in the formation of crystal structures such as mounds and quantum dots (QDs).  Three graduate students are included in this interdisciplinary project.

por.por_cntn:
Epitaxial growth is a process in which a crystalline material is deposited on top of another crystalline material. This process is extensively used in laboratories with the purpose of fabricating many modern optoelectronic devices including transistors, microchips, lasers, memory storage devices, as well as catalysts used in the energy sector, food processing,

biology and environmental science. Therefore, a firm fundamental understanding of the kinetics and thermodynamics of epitaxial growth is crucial for many technological applications that form the foundation of the competitiveness of the US economy today. 


In this project, we have developed analytical and computational tools in order to seamlessly and efficiently connect several models as well as several length and time scales in epitaxial growth. These tools encompass asymptotic techniques for linking atomistic models to mesoscale and macroscopic phenomena as well as efficient numerical methods and computational schemes. We have achieved these results by combining the expertise and knowledge of three PIs who have backgrounds in Mathematics, Physics, and Engineering.


More specifically, our contributions across the distinct scales of epitaxy can be described as follows. At the atomistic level, we have developed new algorithms, called kinetic Monte Carlo methods, in order to study accurately scaling phenomena that appear in the unstable growth of crystal mounds. The related time and length scales have not been studied in such accuracy before. In our atomistic algorithms, each atom participating in the growth process is resolved individually and is allowed to change position with probabilities or rates that can ultimately be determined from highly refined, quantum mechanical methods. Our atomistic methods can now resolve billions of atoms, or even more. In addition, we have developed and implemented a continuum type model for the dynamics of islands and films on crystal surfaces that makes use of modern computer architectures. Our novel methods in this context include highly parallelized computer codes that make use of advances in adaptive grid refinement techniques. The continuum type model in our work treats the evolving epitaxial film as a continuous medium, in a computationally fast and sufficiently accurate fashion, and does not resolve each individual atom. 


A significant and challenging aspect of our work in this direction was the development of criteria and methodologies to ensure that our continuum type model captures all the essential physics of epitaxial growth, even though not every atom is resolved by this model. To this end, by use of analytical techniques, elements of our continuum type model have been seamlessly extracted or derived from the results of our atomistic models and methods. This connection was made possible via the application of techniques of mathematical analysis. Our new models have allowed us to gain insights into epitaxial phenomena at time and length scales that were previously not attainable with similar methods.


The project has involved a number of graduate students and  postdocs in three major US universities. These young researchers were trained in a highly collaborative, interdisciplinary environment under the constant cross-fertilization of ideas in modern aspects of Mathematics, Physics and Engineering. This kind of training is essential for the development of the US workforce across several disciplines including Mathematics, Physics and Engineering.
